reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central element of the essay: evaluating “mostly-great” as a fraction of a “best feasible future,” and the associated claim that many plausible moral views make the target narrow (fussy). If the reference point were arbitrary or dominated by unreachable ceilings, that would significantly undermine the essay’s framing.

However, the critique’s main lever—“best feasible future” being hypersensitive to a speculative theoretical upper bound—is only partly connected to what the essay actually does. The essay defines “best feasible” as ~99.99th percentile of a well‑informed distribution over futures, not as the absolute physical maximum. So merely pointing out that some far-out physics exploit could raise the theoretical ceiling by 10^10 doesn’t, by itself, show the denominator used by the essay will explode, unless that exploit is plausibly within the distribution’s 99.99th percentile. The essay also explicitly discusses bounded vs unbounded and linear scaling views, so some sensitivity-to-scale concerns are already “priced in.”

Still, there is a real underlying worry gestured at: percentile-based ‘best feasible’ can be sensitive to how the distribution is specified (tail assumptions, inclusion of extreme tech trajectories), and that can affect whether “common-sense utopia” lands above or below 0.5. The critique doesn’t develop that point with enough precision to substantially refute the essay’s conclusions, hence low strength.

The critique is clear and focused with little fluff (low dead weight) and it stays on a single issue. Correctness is mixed: the general claim about parameter sensitivity is plausible, but it mischaracterizes the essay as using a speculative physical maximum as the denominator rather than a percentile-of-distribution notion.
title: Astronomical theoretical value ceilings make any achievable future indistinguishable from failure
